summary: Transcript of a U.S. Senate Judiciary Committee oversight hearing with FBI Director Christopher Wray. The hearing covers a wide range of topics including FISA Section 702 reauthorization, hate crimes (particularly anti-Semitic and anti-Muslim incidents), border security, child exploitation (CSAM/sextortion), fentanyl trafficking, election interference, and various allegations of FBI misconduct or politicization. Multiple senators question Director Wray on specific cases and FBI policies.

persons.name: Christopher Wray
persons.context: Primary witness at the hearing, testifying on FBI priorities, threats, and operations. Defends FBI's use of FISA Section 702, discusses hate crimes, cyber threats, and responds to allegations of misconduct.

persons.name: Dick Durbin
persons.context: Presides over the hearing, gives opening remarks focusing on hate crimes, FISA Section 702, and child exploitation. Questions Wray on CSAM and FBI compliance.

persons.name: Lindsey Graham
persons.context: Gives opening remarks focused on border security and threats from Iran, China, and Russia. Questions Wray on threat matrix and terrorism.

persons.name: Sheldon Whitehouse
persons.context: Questions Wray about former FBI agent Charles McGonigal and potential FBI 'shenanigans' during the Hillary Clinton email investigation. Also asks about 702's role against fentanyl trafficking.

persons.name: Chuck Grassley
persons.context: Questions Wray about the 'Biden Family 1023' document, FBI sexual misconduct data, and the Richmond field office anti-Catholic memo.

persons.name: Amy Klobuchar
persons.context: Questions Wray about hate crimes, fentanyl trafficking via social media, and sextortion legislation (SHIELD Act).

persons.name: John Cornyn
persons.context: Questions Wray about restoring FBI reputation, FISA Section 702 targeting rules, and equal justice.

persons.name: Christopher Coons
persons.context: Questions Wray about FISA Section 702 reforms, accountability for misuse, and election security.

persons.name: Mike Lee
persons.context: Aggressively questions Wray about past abuses of FISA Section 702, lack of accountability, and constitutional concerns.

persons.name: Richard Blumenthal
persons.context: Questions Wray about election interference by foreign nations and hate crimes on college campuses.

persons.name: Ted Cruz
persons.context: Questions Wray about alleged FBI politicization and failure to investigate Hunter Biden/Joe Biden corruption allegations based on IRS whistleblower claims.

persons.name: Mazie Hirono
persons.context: Questions Wray about FISA Section 702 safeguards, domestic violent extremism, and sex trafficking of Native Hawaiian women.

persons.name: Josh Hawley
persons.context: Questions Wray about FBI targeting of Catholics (Richmond memo) and alleged personal use of FBI jets.

persons.name: Laphonza Butler
persons.context: Questions Wray about attacks on reproductive health clinics post-Dobbs, hate crimes broadly, and attacks on the electric grid.

persons.name: Tom Cotton
persons.context: Questions Wray about anti-Semitic attacks, specifically the mob targeting of AIPAC president Michael Tuchin's home.

persons.name: Jon Ossoff
persons.context: Questions Wray about sextortion crimes targeting children, fentanyl in schools, and threats to Georgia's Jewish and Muslim communities.

persons.name: John Kennedy
persons.context: Questions Wray about the Mar-a-Lago raid, FBI interactions with social media companies, and the Hunter Biden laptop.

persons.name: Cory Booker
persons.context: Questions Wray about building trust with Muslim/Arab-American communities, AI in law enforcement, and FISA Section 702 safeguards.

persons.name: Marsha Blackburn
persons.context: Questions Wray about FBI's handling of Jeffrey Epstein case and the special counsel's search warrant for Trump's Twitter data.

persons.name: Charles McGonigal
persons.context: Former FBI agent who pled guilty to receiving money from a foreign national. Senator Whitehouse raises questions about his knowledge of potential misconduct in the New York field office during the Hillary Clinton investigation.

persons.name: Hunter Biden
persons.context: Referenced by Senators Grassley and Cruz regarding an alleged bribery scheme and ongoing investigation. Cruz references a WhatsApp text message Hunter allegedly sent to a Chinese national.

persons.name: Joe Biden
persons.context: Referenced by Senator Cruz in allegations of corruption related to Hunter Biden. Cruz references a text message implying Joe Biden was present during an alleged shakedown attempt.

persons.name: Merrick Garland
persons.context: Referenced by Senator Cruz, who alleges Garland lied under oath about not interfering in the Hunter Biden investigation.

persons.name: David Weiss
persons.context: Special Counsel leading the investigation into Hunter Biden. Director Wray repeatedly defers questions about the investigation to him.

persons.name: James Comey
persons.context: Referenced by Senators Whitehouse and Cornyn regarding his handling of the Hillary Clinton email investigation and alleged violations of DOJ rules.

persons.name: Rudy Giuliani
persons.context: Referenced by Senator Whitehouse as allegedly pressuring Director Comey to intervene in the Hillary Clinton campaign.

persons.name: Hillary Clinton
persons.context: Referenced by Senators Whitehouse and Cornyn regarding the FBI's investigation into her email server and Director Comey's public statements.

persons.name: Donald Trump
persons.context: Referenced by Senators Cornyn, Cotton, Kennedy, and Blackburn regarding investigations (Russiagate, Mar-a-Lago documents, Twitter search warrant) and alleged unfair treatment.

persons.name: Jeffrey Epstein
persons.context: Referenced by Senator Blackburn, who alleges the FBI failed to properly investigate his sex trafficking ring and calls for release of flight logs.

persons.name: Michael Tuchin
persons.context: Victim of an anti-Semitic mob that attacked his home on Thanksgiving. Senator Cotton questions why the FBI hasn't made arrests.

persons.name: Wadea Al-Fayoume
persons.context: Six-year-old Palestinian-American boy fatally stabbed in Illinois, mentioned by Chairman Durbin as an example of a hate crime.

connections.description: Durbin, as Committee Chairman, oversees and questions FBI Director Wray on a range of issues including FISA 702, hate crimes, and child exploitation.
Graham, as Ranking Member, questions Wray on border security, threat matrix, and terrorism.
Wray is the current FBI Director; McGonigal is a former FBI agent who pled guilty to crimes. Wray states the FBI's counterintelligence division identified McGonigal's wrongdoing.
Father and son. Central to allegations by Senators Grassley and Cruz about an alleged bribery scheme.
Special Counsel Weiss is leading the ongoing investigation into Hunter Biden.
As FBI Director, Comey led the investigation into Clinton's email server and made public statements about it.
Senator Whitehouse references reports that Giuliani and NY FBI agents pressured Comey to intervene in the Clinton campaign.
Senator Cruz accuses Attorney General Garland of lying under oath about interfering in the Hunter Biden investigation.

connections.context: Senator Blackburn criticizes the FBI's past handling of the Epstein case and demands a complete investigation.

events.title: Hamas terrorist attacks in Israel
events.description: Hamas's horrific terrorist attacks in Israel, cited as a catalyst for increased threats and hate crimes globally and in the U.S.

events.title: Senate Judiciary FBI Oversight Hearing
events.description: Hearing with FBI Director Christopher Wray covering FISA 702, hate crimes, border security, child exploitation, fentanyl, and allegations of FBI misconduct.

events.title: FBI 1023 document serialized
events.description: An FBI FD-1023 form alleging a bribery scheme involving the Biden family was serialized. Referenced by Senator Grassley.

events.title: Plot to attack Knoxville FBI office
events.description: A man from Tennessee pled guilty to a plot to attack the Knoxville FBI office and kill agents involved in January 6th investigations.

events.title: Murder of Wadea Al-Fayoume
events.description: Six-year-old Palestinian-American boy fatally stabbed in Illinois in a hate crime.

events.title: Attack on Michael Tuchin's home
events.description: A pro-Palestinian mob attacked the home of AIPAC president Michael Tuchin on Thanksgiving, vandalizing property and assaulting a neighbor.

events.title: Declassification of FBI query abuse report
events.description: Director of National Intelligence report declassified detailing an FBI analyst querying 702 data based on a tip from his mother about his father having an affair.

events.title: Richmond Field Office anti-Catholic memo
events.description: FBI Richmond field office produced an intelligence product assessing 'Radical Traditionalist Catholic Ideology' and potential infiltration. Withdrawn by Director Wray.

keyFacts: FBI Director Christopher Wray testified that the threat environment is uniquely elevated with 'blinking lights everywhere I turn,' citing threats from foreign adversaries, terrorism, cyberattacks, and hate crimes.

A major focus was the reauthorization of FISA Section 702, which Wray called indispensable for national security. He cited a 98% compliance rate post-reforms but faced sharp criticism from some senators over past abuses.

There was significant discussion of a sharp rise in hate crimes, especially anti-Semitic and anti-Muslim incidents, since the October 7th Hamas attacks. Wray stated the FBI had opened 60% more hate crime investigations post-October 7th.

Multiple Republican senators (Grassley, Cruz, Hawley, Blackburn) raised allegations of FBI politicization, including the handling of the Hunter Biden investigation, the 'Biden Family 1023' document, the anti-Catholic memo, and the Mar-a-Lago search.
Senator Marsha Blackburn directly questioned why the FBI had not fully investigated Jeffrey Epstein's sex trafficking ring and called for transparency, including the release of flight logs.
